questions.question: What is the difference between descriptive and inferential statistics?

options.A: Descriptive statistics are used to make predictions, while inferential statistics summarize data.
options.B: Descriptive statistics summarize data, while inferential statistics are used to make generalizations about a population based on a sample.
options.C: Descriptive statistics deal with qualitative data, while inferential statistics deal with quantitative data.
options.D: There is no significant difference between them.

questions.question: Which of the following is a measure of central tendency?

options.A: Standard deviation
options.B: Variance
options.C: Median
options.D: Range

questions.question: What does the variance of a dataset measure?

options.A: The central value of the data.
options.B: The spread or dispersion of the data around the mean.
options.C: The shape of the data distribution.
options.D: The most frequent value in the data.

questions.question: What is a probability distribution?

options.A: A table that shows the frequency of each value in a dataset.
options.B: A function that describes the likelihood of different outcomes in a random experiment.
options.C: A graph that displays the relationship between two variables.
options.D: A measure of the central tendency of a dataset.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a discrete probability distribution?

options.A: Normal distribution
options.B: Exponential distribution
options.C: Binomial distribution
options.D: Uniform distribution (continuous)

questions.question: What is the Central Limit Theorem?

options.A: It states that the mean of any sample will always be equal to the population mean.
options.B: It describes the shape of the population distribution.
options.C: It states that the distribution of sample means will tend to be normally distributed as the sample size increases, regardless of the shape of the original population distribution.
options.D: It is used to calculate the probability of rare events.

questions.question: What is a hypothesis test?

options.A: A method for calculating the mean of a sample.
options.B: A procedure for using sample data to evaluate a claim about a population.
options.C: A way to visualize the distribution of data.
options.D: A technique for cleaning and preprocessing data.

questions.question: What is the null hypothesis ($H_0$) in hypothesis testing?

options.A: The hypothesis that the researcher is trying to prove.
options.B: A statement of no effect or no difference.
options.C: The alternative hypothesis.
options.D: The hypothesis based on the sample data.

questions.question: What is the p-value in hypothesis testing?

options.A: The probability of the null hypothesis being true.
options.B: The significance level of the test.
options.C: The probability of observing data as extreme as, or more extreme than, the data collected if the null hypothesis were true.
options.D: The probability of the alternative hypothesis being true.

questions.question: What is the significance level ($alpha$) in hypothesis testing?

options.A: The probability of making a Type II error.
options.B: A pre-determined threshold used to decide whether to reject the null hypothesis.
options.C: The p-value of the test.
options.D: The power of the test.

questions.question: What is a Type I error in hypothesis testing?

options.A: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis.
options.B: Rejecting a true null hypothesis.
options.C: Incorrectly calculating the p-value.
options.D: Choosing the wrong statistical test.

questions.question: What is a Type II error in hypothesis testing?

options.A: Rejecting a true null hypothesis.
options.B: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis.
options.C: Using an inappropriate significance level.
options.D: Misinterpreting the results of the test.

questions.question: What is correlation?

options.A: A measure of the central tendency of two variables.
options.B: A statistical measure that describes the extent to which two variables tend to change together.
options.C: A visual representation of the relationship between two variables.
options.D: A method for predicting future values based on past data.

questions.question: What does a correlation coefficient of -1 indicate?

options.A: A strong positive linear relationship.
options.B: No linear relationship.
options.C: A strong negative linear relationship.
options.D: A perfect non-linear relationship.

questions.question: What is regression analysis?

options.A: A method for summarizing data using descriptive statistics.
options.B: A statistical technique used to model the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.
options.C: A way to group data points into clusters.
options.D: A technique for visualizing the distribution of a single variable.

questions.question: In simple linear regression, what does the slope of the regression line represent?

options.A: The average value of the dependent variable.
options.B: The change in the dependent variable for a one-unit increase in the independent variable.
options.C: The point where the regression line intersects the y-axis.
options.D: The strength of the linear relationship between the variables.

questions.question: What is statistical power?

options.A: The probability of making a Type I error.
options.B: The probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis.
options.C: The significance level of the test.
options.D: The size of the sample used in the hypothesis test.

questions.question: What is the difference between a population and a sample?

options.A: A population is a subset of a sample.
options.B: A sample is a subset of a population.
options.C: Population refers to categorical data, while sample refers to numerical data.
options.D: There is no difference between them in statistical analysis.

questions.question: What is sampling bias?

options.A: A random error that occurs during data collection.
options.B: A systematic error that occurs when the sample is not representative of the population.
options.C: A bias introduced during the analysis phase.
options.D: A bias caused by outliers in the data.

questions.question: Why are statistical foundations important for data analytics?

options.A: They are not really necessary; intuition is sufficient.
options.B: They provide the framework for understanding data, drawing valid inferences, and making informed decisions based on evidence.
options.C: They are only important for academic research, not practical applications.
options.D: They primarily dictate the choice of visualization techniques.
